misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of summing the even numbers among 5 input integers. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the task is to read initial velocity, final velocity, and time, then compute and print the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Variables and calculations are for average acceleration, not for summing even integers.
No use of modulo operator (%) or any check for even numbers.
No loop or any mechanism to process exactly 5 inputs as required.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the written problem requirements or reuse of code for a different exercise without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify the required inputs (5 integers), the selection criterion (even numbers using n % 2 == 0), and the desired output (sum of the even inputs) before writing any code.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program—prompt, input variables, and formula—matches an acceleration problem and does not attempt any part of the specified "sum of even numbers" task.

evidence.note: The code clearly implements an average acceleration calculator instead of reading 5 integers, checking evenness, and summing the even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect input quantity and types (3 doubles instead of 5 integers)
misconceptions.description: The student reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers as specified. This shows a misunderstanding of the required input contract for the program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program should prompt for and read three numeric values representing velocities and time using nextDouble().
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly five integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt()), which will then be examined to sum only the even ones.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for three values (v0, v1, t).
Exactly three calls to nextDouble(), no use of nextInt().
No mechanism to read five separate integers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between this assignment and a different exercise, or not paying attention to the specified number and type of inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, write down the exact input format: how many values, of what type, and in what order. Use that as a checklist when writing your Scanner code (e.g., five nextInt() calls or a loop that runs exactly five times).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and three nextDouble() calls clearly contradict the requirement to read 5 integers, and there is no other input logic present.

evidence.note: Three double values are read instead of five integers, and there is no loop or additional input to reach five numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting Assignment Requirements (Wrong Problem Solved)
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates average acceleration instead of implementing the required program to find the sum of five even integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this code satisfies the assignment requirements, possibly due to submitting the wrong file or confusing the problems.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 distinct integers, iterating through them (implicitly requiring a loop), checking for evenness, and accumulating their sum.
symptoms: The program asks for velocity and time variables instead of 5 integers
The core logic calculates acceleration
There is no loop structure
No conditional check for even numbers exists
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented and submitted a solution for a different problem, completely failing to address the requirements of Q1: Sum of Even Numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please double-check that the submitted code directly addresses the prompt for Q1, which involves reading 5 integers and calculating a sum, not acceleration.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, inputs, calculation, and output all relate to calculating acceleration and bear no resemblance to the required solution for summing even numbers.

evidence.note: The class name 'AccelerationCalculator' immediately indicates an incorrect problem context.
The input prompt asks for three variables used in physics (v0, v1, t), instead of prompting for five integers.
The core calculation computes average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have misunderstood the problem entirely. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers, the student wrote a program to calculate acceleration from three velocity/time inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment is asking them to calculate average acceleration using the formula (finalVelocity - v0) / time, based on three inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user and calculating the sum of only the even numbers among those 5 integers. The acceleration calculator is a completely different problem.
symptoms: Program reads only 3 inputs instead of 5
Program performs physics calculation instead of filtering even numbers
Output message does not match expected 'Sum of even numbers' format
Uses double instead of int (inappropriate for this problem)
No loop structure for processing multiple inputs
No conditional logic to check if numbers are even
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misreading or misunderstanding of the problem statement. The student may have confused this assignment with a different problem, or failed to read the requirements carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement. The task is to: (1) read 5 integers, (2) loop through them, (3) check which ones are even using n % 2 == 0, (4) sum only the even numbers, and (5) print the result. Start from scratch with the correct problem in mind.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) than what is asked (sum of even numbers). The mismatch is unambiguous.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates acceleration from physics inputs, not the sum of even numbers from 5 integers as required.
Prompt asks for physics variables (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers as specified in the problem.

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the problem statement and list the exact requirements (number of inputs, types of inputs, required condition for selection, and the final output). Then design your algorithm step-by-step to match those requirements before coding.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, variable names, prompt, and formula are aligned with a different physics problem and do not address any part of the stated requirement to sum even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: This code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration instead of reading 5 integers, checking for even numbers, summing them, and printing the sum.
